title: Protocol for producing an adeno-associated virus vector by controlling capsid expression timing
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparing HEK293 cells – Day 0
Timing: 12–24 h
Plate HEK293 cells in a Minimum Essential Medium (MEM)-containing plate containing 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and non-essential amino acid (NEAA) (If possible, it would be better not add antibiotics to the culture medium at this time).
Note: The cell seeding number depends on the culture scale.
Check cell confluency before transfection.
Note: Cells should reach 80%–90% confluency by observing under microscope at the time of transfection.
Note: Cell condition is one of the crucial factors for AAV vector production. If the condition is poor, including the presence of strange cell shapes, use a new cell stock to properly produce AAV vectors.
Transfection of AAV plasmids – Day 1–5
Timing: 1 h (for step 3)
Timing: 1 h (for steps 4 to 8)
Four plasmids containing the AAV genome, adeno virus helper genes, Tet-Cap, and CMV-Rep2 are co-transfected into HEK293 cells for AAV vector production. Plasmids for conventional AAV vector transfection can be prepared as control. For comparison, the plasmid transfection volume must be adjusted similarly by adding an empty plasmid. Any transfection reagents can be used for this protocol.
Transfect plasmids to HEK293 cells.
Small scale (such as 6-, 12-, or 24-well-plates).
Commercialized transfection reagents can be used according to manufacturer’s instructions. (Example; HilyMax https://www.dojindo.co.jp/manual/H357e.pdf[href=https://www.dojindo.co.jp/manual/H357e.pdf], Lipofectamine 3000 https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Flipofectamine3000_protocol.pdf[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Flipofectamine3000_protocol.pdf])
Prepare Opti-MEM medium in a tube (the suitable medium volume depends on transfection reagent)
Add plasmids to the tube in the following ratio:

All plasmids are added in a tube containing Opti-MEM medium.
Add transfection reagent to each tube according to manufacturer’s instructions.
Mix samples well by vortex (it depends on manufacturer’s instructions) and incubate them for 10–20 min at room temperature (RT; 20°C–25°C).
Add samples dropwise to each well for plasmid transfection into cells.

Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2, 90%–95% humidity for 12 h in a CO2 incubator.
Large scale (such as T225 flask, Cell Factory [2528 cm2]]).
Prepare PEI-MAX solution and 150 mM NaCl solution.
The following protocol is for transfection using Cell Factory (Culture medium; 400–500 mL.
Prepare 50 mL (1/10 volume of culture medium) of 150 mM NaCl solution in a 225 mL tube.
Add plasmids to the tube in the following ratio:
table:files/protocols_protocol_3185_13.csv
All plasmids are added in a tube containing 150 mM NaCl solution.
Add 6825 μg of PEI-MAX (3.5-fold to total DNA amount (μg)) to each tube.
Note: The volume of PEI-MAX needs to be optimized to obtain best results by your cell condition such as transfection efficiency and cytotoxicity against DNA and reagents.
Mix samples well by up-side-down and incubate them for 20 min at RT.
Take approximately 100 mL of culture medium from culture flask and add it to a new tube.
Add the plasmids mixture to 100 mL of culture medium and mix well (the total volume is approximately 150 mL).
Return the mixture to the flask for plasmid transfection into cells and mix the medium gently.
Incubate the cells at 37°C for 12 h in a CO2 incubator.
Note: Cells must be adherent in this transfection step to obtain maximum AAV vector production. If some cells float during transfection, the efficacy of AAV vector production decreases.
At 12 h post-transfection, prepare fresh, warmed complete culture medium.
Add doxycycline (Dox) with a final 2 μg/mL concentration to fresh medium.
Discard culture medium from the flask.
Add fresh complete medium containing Dox in the flask.
Incubate cells at 37°C in a CO2 incubator for 3 days (small scale) or 4 days (large scale).

Note: Generally, adding Dox at 10–15 h post transfection is advantageous for efficient AAV vector production. However, vector production efficiency may depend on the cell condition and experiments.
Harvest cells and supernatants – Day 5
Timing: 1–2 h
Prepare the AAV lysis buffer, 1 × phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), chilled 5 mM EDTA/PBS solution on ice, and 40% PEG solution.
Harvest cells and supernatants.
Small scale.
Prepare the tubes for the samples.
Pipette the culture medium to detach all cells from plate.
Collect the cells and supernatant in a tube.
Store samples in −80°C before use.
Large scale.
Prepare the tubes for the samples.
Collect the culture supernatants in tubes and add 1/4 volume of 40% PEG solution, and store the mixture at 4°C for at least 4 h after mixing well until AAV vector collection in supernatants in subsequent steps.
Note: Only supernatant is needed to harvest AAV vector in culture meidum at this moment. Detached cells may exist in supernatant at this step. These cells can be separated from the supernatant by centrifugation, and the cell pellet can be mixed with sample at step b-5.
Carefully wash the cells using 1 × PBS while avoiding detaching cells, and discard PBS.
Note: If many detached cells are present in this step, collect the samples in a tube and mix them according to step b-5.
After the PBS wash, add 100 mL of ice-chilled 5 mM EDTA/PBS solution to the cell flask, and incubate the cells at RT for 10–15 min to detach the cells.
Collect solutions containing cells in a tube, and centrifuge at 2000–3000 × g for 10 min, and then discard the supernatant.
Wash the flask with 100 mL PBS and collect the cells in tubes.
Repeat step b-5 twice to collect the cells from the flask completely.

Centrifuge samples at 2000–3000 × g for 10 min, and then discard the supernatant.
Note: If the entire volume of supernatant cannot be collected in a tube, centrifugation can be performed separately for each wash sample.
Discard the supernatant and keep the pellets on ice or in −80°C before use.
Centrifuge the supernatants-PEG mix (after the 4-h 4°C incubation) from step b-2, at 2000–3000 × g for 20 min.
Discard the supernatant, and dissolve the supernatant-pellet in 8–10 mL of AAV lysis buffer.
Add dissolved samples (step b-11) to each tube containing cell pellet at step b-9, and store samples at −80°C before use.
Pause point: You can stop experiment after freezing samples.
AAV vector extraction and purification – Day 5–6
Timing: 1–2 days (for steps 11 to 34)
For AAV vector extraction and purification, you can use global standard methods.10[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10],11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11] Ultracentrifuge steps to purify AAV vectors require items described in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A and key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3185-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Ultracentrifuge for AAV vector purification
(A) Items used for ultracentrifugation to purify AAV vectors.
(B) Diagram of layers containing AAV vectors before and after ultracentrifugation.
(C) The position of the needle to collect AAV vectors after centrifugation.
Extract AAV vectors
Prepare a 37°C water bath and liquid nitrogen (or cold ethanol using dry ice).
Incubate the frozen samples in a 37°C water bath for 10–15 min until they have thawed entirely.
Mix the samples well by vortexing for 10–20 s.
Then place samples in liquid nitrogen (or cold ethanol using dry ice) for 20 min until completely frozen.
Repeat steps 12–14 thrice (four times in total).
Centrifuge the samples at 5000–8000 × g for 10 min to pellet the cell debris.
Transfer the supernatants to new tubes (The supernatants comprise the crude AAV vector solutions).

Note: For small scale preparations, you can filter the supernatants using 0.22 μm syringe-top filter to eliminate cell debris after centrifugation (step b-16).
Digest free DNAs in solution with a DNase treatment.
[Small scale]
Prepare DNase solution, such as Turbo DNase, according to manufacturer’s instructions.
Take 4 μL of sample and digest free DNAs in a 20 μL reaction volume. Example: TURBO DNase or TURBO DNA-free kit (ThermoFisher)
table:files/protocols_protocol_3185_14.csv
Incubate the samples at 37°C for at least 4 h.
After the reaction, inactivate the DNase according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
(For example, inactivate DNase by adding 1 μL of inactivation reagent from the Turbo DNA free kit and mixing samples well. Centrifuge samples at 8,000–10,000 × g for 5 min and then collect supernatants into a new tube for elimination of DNase.)
Add 1 volume of water to dilute DNase-treat samples.
Note: Samples are diluted with 1/10 from the initial concentration.
Note: Because AAV vector yield by small scale is small, samples before DNase treatment (step 17) can be used for various assay. However, the step of DNase treatment (step 18) is required to check AAV vector titer in solution (Quantification; step 34–40).
Proceed to the quantification step.
[Large scale]
Add benzonase with 50 units/mL as the final concentration to each tube.
Incubate the samples for at least 4 h at 37°C.
Proceed to the purification step.
Purify AAV vectors
Prepare ultracentrifugation tubes and 54, 40, 25, 15% Opti-prep (Iodixanol) buffers.
Note: Opti-prep buffers should be prepared ahead of time.
Layer 54, 40, 25, and 15% Opti-prep gradients (from the bottom to the top) in ultracentrifugation tubes (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B) slowly to not mix layers.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3185_15.csv
Apply the sample (step 18 b-3) on top of the 15% layer.

If making multiple samples can add AAV lysis buffer to the top for balance.
Perform ultracentrifugation at 30,000–40,000 rpm (approximately 170,000–280,000 × g) for 6–15 h at 4°C–10°C.
Note: Normally, centrifugation is performed for 12–15 h (overnight).
Check the layers after ultracentrifugation and collect the entire second layer from the bottom (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B and 1C), which contains full and empty AAV vectors, with syringe.
Note: The second layer contains full (including AAV genome) and empty AAV particles. To select the portion containing full AAV vectors, the fractionation for second layer can be performed.
Note: If further purification is needed, re-ultracentrifugation can be performed using the samples in this step.
Add 1 volume of AAV lysis buffer to dilute the sample.
Prepare Amicon Ultra 100 kDa MWCO column (4 mL or 15 mL, Merk) by adding 4–15 mL of AAV lysis buffer to pre-wash the membrane, and then centrifuging the column at 3000 × g for 5 min.
Discard the flow-through, and immediately add the sample (at step 25) to the pre-washed column.
Centrifuge the sample at 3,500–4,000 × g for 40–60 min.
Note: Samples are sticky and may not easily pass through the column. In this case, increase the centrifugation time until most samples pass through the column.
Add 4 mL of fresh AAV lysis buffer to wash the column (If you use a 15 mL column, add 15 mL of AAV lysis buffer)
Centrifuge the sample at 3,500–4,000 × g for 20–40 min.
Note: Adjust the optimal remaining volume of solution in the column by centrifugation time.
(Optional) Wash column by repeating step 29–30.
Collect the remaining solution above the column, which contains AAV vectors.
Filter sample further using a 0.45 μm syringe.
Aliquot AAV vector solutions into tubes and keep them in −20°C or −80°C before use.

Note: Because AAV vectors are usually stable, they can be stored at 4°C for short periods.
Pause point: You can stop experiment after finishing this step.
Quantification of AAV vectors – Day 7
Timing: 3–4 h
To use the produced AAV vector for various assays, you need to determine the AAV vector titer using quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) or other methods.
Prepare the qPCR reagent, primer sets targeting the inverted terminal repeat (ITR), standard (quantified AAV vector, plasmid containing AAV genome, fragment of ITR), and samples.
Prepare 107, 106, 105, 104, 103, 102 vg/μL of standard samples and a negative control.
Place the standard and samples in separate wells in a PCR plate in duplicate or triplicate, and seal the plate.
Incubate the plate at 95°C for 10 min to denature AAV vectors.
Note: Instead of DNA plasmids or fragments, we recommend using viral particles for the standard and denaturing them together with samples in the same plate because the efficacy of AAV genome release from particles and capsid proteins in the reaction may affect the qPCR result.
Prepare the qPCR master mix, including primers, according to manufacturer’s instructions.
(As example of a qPCR reaction with a reaction volume of 20 μL): 1 μL of sample, 12.5 μL of 2 × qPCR buffer, 0.1 μL of primer 1 (10 μM), 0.1 μL of primer 2 (10 μM), 11.3 μL of pure water).
(Example; TB Green Premix Ex Taq II https://www.takarabio.com/documents/User%20Manual/RR82LR/RR82LR_UM.pdf[href=https://www.takarabio.com/documents/User%20Manual/RR82LR/RR82LR_UM.pdf])
Note: The concentration of the samples in this protocol are 1/10 dilution from the original samples.
Perform the qPCR reaction according to manufacturer’s instructions.
Note: The reaction conditions depend on the reagents and instrument. Fast and conventional PCR cycles are applicable.
Analyze AAV vector titer in samples.

Note: After determining the AAV vector titer, these vectors can be used for various assays such as enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), western blots, immunoprecipitation, infection studies on cells and injection into mouse models.
Note: After aliquoting, the AAV vectors can be kept at −20 or −80°C for long-term storage, at 4°C for short-term storage, for 1–2 weeks, before use.
